title: Can anyone prove that atoms exist? - Quora

response.answer_text: Technically, atoms do not exist at all. They are a useful MODEL that we use to describe mass-matter. Atoms exist “on paper”. Every atom in the Universe has the same basic composition (on paper). The construct of atoms differs from model to model. The most common model is one where protons and neutrons are compactly and tightly crammed in the core of the atom (called the nucleus) and electrons orbit said nucleus. A second model that is preferred by Quantum Physicists, is the one in which the three particles are waves. Matter waves to be exact. Electrons are not particles in this model. They are, rather, standing waves with an integer number of wavelengths that enclose the so-called spherical shell of the orbit. Ditto for the protons and neutrons; for they too are considered to be matter-waves. A third model is akin to the second, but it takes it one further step: each nucleon (particles that exist in the nucleus) us made of three “quarks” which are vibrating strings. It is unfortunate that when we speak of atoms, we totally forget, or ignore, the concept of Fundamental Quantities (FQ). There are SEVEN FQ in our Universe. The top four are: 1) Space (as in “distance”); 2) Time; 3) Matter (mass and/or energy); 4) Charge. A FQ is a quantity that CANNOT be defined but it can be MEASURED. The particles mentioned above have FQ as their properties. Since we cannot define FQ, it follows that we cannot define these particles, and hence, we cannot say how atoms exist because they contain matter with properties unknown to us. The electrons, protons and quarks have FQ of mass/energy and charge and they have properties of speed, hence they have the FQ of Space and Time. Even neutrons, that are technically neutral in charge, can be considered to have charge, because they are believed to be made of quarks. The quarks that make up a neutron do have charge. It so happens that their charge adds up to zero. Since our models of atoms are constructs of matter that are basically FQ, we can say that we really cannot say that atoms exist. Conclusion: atoms exist only “on paper”.

It makes more sense if you were to continually cut something in half, you’d never be able to stop. You should ask yourself: why should that make sense? And how did you determine that should make “more sense” than something else? Like, how did you weigh the amount of sense each of these two ideas makes? This isn’t an insult. Those are real questions! So, we came up with experiments to determine how the universe behaves; which actually makes “more sense”. And for the purposes of this discussion, scientific observation says that atoms make “more sense”. They make so much sense… we can draw pictures with them.  But why can’t you keep dividing? Why is there a limit?  Well, let’s take a detour. Suppose you’re traveling at 1 meter per second. You should be able to keep doubling your speed, right? It makes no sense that there should be any speed limit. So just keep doubling it! Except, our scientific observations show that there is a speed limit. So, it certainly does “make sense”; that’s what’s real. Our previous understanding of how things “should work” was faulty. It’s very similar. It sounds “simple” that you should just be able to keep cutting matter apart into infinitely smaller halves. Except, no. You can’t. That’s just how it is.  Now, your question asks “how do atoms exist”? That can be answered at different levels of complexity. Judging from the question, I think you’re looking for a “big picture” question of HOW. Simple answer: we don’t know how. … Okay, okay. We do know how. See, atoms are not the smallest things in the universe. There are sub-atomic particles: for examples, protons, electrons, and neutrons. And we have a very decent theory for describing how those particles combine into atoms. (And then very interestingly, we know that both protons and neutrons can be divided further into “thirds”… but electrons cannot be divided further!) So, I think you’re really asking, “Why atoms?” And again, you can answer that at different levels of complexity. But I think a few different big-picture answers are most appropriate: So, why not atoms? Which isn’t really an answer. And yet, this is the only answer we can really answer. Tell me how you think things work, and I’ll try to tell you why it doesn’t work that way. No matter how much we do this and I answer “why not”, I can’t seem to ever tell you a positive “why”.Science isn’t very good at answering some kinds of “why” questions. We can tell you what is or by what process something follows. But there is no more fundamental answer about preference—except to look for deeper theories.Now let’s have a little thought experiment. If you could continually cut something in half and “you’d never be able to stop”, that suggests that the finite size of an atom can be divided into an infinite amount of stuff. This raises… difficult questions.One thing we often observe is summed up in a common saying: “Nature abhors infinities.” This isn’t technically or mathematically true, but expresses a rather deep idea. There is a very large difference (heh) between mind-bendingly large numbers… and infinity.Someone once joked that time exists so everything doesn’t happen all at once. And likewise, that space exists so that everything does have to happen at the same place. These are very simplistic statements, but can you accept that as making logical sense?Well, I think it’s simplest to say that the existence of atoms guarantees that everything doesn’t happen at one time, and one place.Or… from a different perspective, that what we perceive as atoms are the happening of everything not happening in one place, at one time. … According to some rather simple rules we have observed about how the universe operates.And so why? Hmm. Well, I do suppose the universe would be rather dull if everything happened all at once, at only one place. When you get into these deep questions, it’s best to have a bit of a sense of humor about it.

Chemists in the 18th and 19th century had collected a lot of data about how elements and compounds interacted. The best explanation that they had for their observations was that the smallest unit of an element was a single particle (an “atom”), and compounds were formed by small collections of these elemental particles. Hydrogen gas was made of two particles of hydrogen; carbon dioxide had two particles of oxygen and one particle of carbon; baking soda has one particle of hydrogen, one of sodium, one of carbon, and three of oxygen, etc. So the idea that many had was the “atomic theory”, that matter was made of atoms that were too small to see and were indivisible. Each element had a different type of atom, and compounds are made by atoms interacting. The rules for how atoms interacted were mostly known. But some didn’t fully accept the atomic theory. The main problem was a lack of corroborating evidence for these particles that were too small to see. It explained things like how chemistry worked, but maybe it was all an accounting trick, and the actual atoms didn’t really exist. Two things changed that. The first was in 1827 when Robert Brown looked at pollen through a microscope. It was floating in water, but it was dancing around, not staying put. The pollen grains would jiggle and jounce, apparently randomly, for no visible reason. Brown wrote up these observations, and the weird motion was studied with no explanation for the motion, for the rest of the century. The second was in 1905, when Albert Einstein wrote a paper that explained the Brownian motion using the atomic theory and statistical mechanics. The motion of the pollen grains was exactly what you would expect if the pollen was being randomly hit from all sides by fast-moving, small particles. By studying the statistics of the random motion (how far the grains would move in a straight line before being hit enough to change it’s direction or speed, how fast the grains would move along its path, the average distance the grains would go over time, etc), Einstein was able to calculate the size and momentum of the small particles that were pushing the grains around. It was a close match to what the atomic theory said had to be the case for atoms and molecules. After Einstein’s paper, the opposition to the atomic theory fell greatly, and it quickly became the scientific consensus. There were other experiments which cemented the issue, as well.

How do atoms exist? It makes more sense if you were to continually cut something in half, you’d never be able to stop. Well, when you get down to a certain point, you are not actually cutting something in half anymore. That only works when things are completely homogeneous. For example, if you have a house, you can tell its a house, it has a roof, floors, wall, doors and windows, etc. If you cut it in half, you can tell you have two half houses, but, not two houses. If you take one half a house, and cut it again, you have a quarter house, and so forth. At some point you get down to a brick over there, a piece of wood over here, a pane of glass, some mortar, a nail, a screw, etc… but, none of those things is “a house”. So, an atom of hydrogen for example, is just a proton and an electron… and, if you break it, there’s no “half”, as one part is a tiny electron and one part is a much much larger proton… … so, you get an electron, which is not hydrogen any more, and a proton, which is not hydrogen anymore. So, we CAN’T break the electron down further, as it an elementary particle… we know of no “parts” for it. We CAN break down a proton, into 2 up quarks (u), and 1 down quark (d)… but, can’t break THOSE down any further, as quarks are also elementary particles. So, yes, if things were 100% homogeneous, and, you were to keeping cutting them in half, you could just keep going, until perhaps a Planck length or so. :D

Early atomic theory predicted that electrons passing through a thin sheet of gold would be scattered by something in the gold (atoms). Some would pass straight through the spaces between atoms but some would bounce of the atoms. The pattern of some passing through and some bouncing off was observed, indicating that there was something to the theory. Had nothing passed through or had nothing been scattered the theory would have been disproved, perhaps proving that atoms did not exist, but the theory survived the test. Strictly speaking, it is not possible to prove atoms exist, but it is possible to predict what would happen if atoms do not exist (there would be no scattering or no pass-through). The theory that atoms do not exist was disproved, leaving the theory that atoms actually do exist. For the thinking and standards of ordinary, non-scientific, life this experiment “proved” atoms exist.

Can you effectively cut water in a glass in half with a knife? The issue here is that the smaller the things get the less tangible they become in nature. Subatomic particles really more resemble “forcefields” than anything else. Furthermore, these particles can lack a precise location at any given time and essentially exist in many locations at the same time. So, if something has such properties it would be rather challenging to “cut” it, if at all. It stands to reason that something which you are trying to cut should be thicker than the knife’s edge. Now, atoms themselves exhibit forces which make these “forcefields” of subatomic particles stick together. And such forces can be overcome causing the atom to split up. That primarily is done by imparting great energies to the atom via shooting it with some particle making it unstable and causing it to break, rather than it being “cut”. So, it is more of a kick than a cut. But imparting such forces to subatomic particles becomes tricky. Just like it might be tricky to hit a golf ball with a 747 airplane. The things which we can effectively use to impart this energy become much bigger than the target, making it impossible to hit. And even if hit it would probably bounce off rather than break apart.
